DOCNAME: CASE OF BAHADDAR v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection allowed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies)
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON is a NORP national born in DATE . He is currently resident in the GPE .
CARDINAL . Mr ORG arrived in the GPE on DATE . On CARDINAL DATE he lodged applications for refugee status or , in the alternative , a residence permit on humanitarian grounds .

CARDINAL . With the assistance of a NORP interpreter , PERSON ORG was interviewed by an official of ORG ( PERSON Justitie ) on CARDINAL DATE . He claimed to have been a member of the illegal organisation PERSON ( ORG ) , the military wing of ORG ( ORG , an organisation seeking autonomy for the inhabitants of LOC ) , and to be in danger of persecution on that ground .

Mr ORG ’s applications for refugee status or , in the alternative , a residence permit on humanitarian grounds were refused on DATE by the Deputy Minister of ORG ( ORG ) . The applicant then applied to the Deputy Minister for revision ( herziening ) of this decision .

CARDINAL . The Deputy Minister refused to grant suspensive effect to Mr ORG ’s application for revision of his decision . In order to obtain an injunction against his expulsion pending the revision proceedings , the applicant instigated summary injunction proceedings ( kort geding ) before the President of ORG ( Arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE sitting at ’s - Hertogenbosch ( nevenzittingsplaats ’s - Hertogenbosch ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President granted the injunction requested . The President found the applicant ’s story consistent and credible .
CARDINAL . The applicant was heard by ORG concerning Aliens ( PERSON voor ORG ) on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG expressed the opinion that the applicant was not a refugee within the meaning of the DATE LAW relating to ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and that he was not eligible for a residence permit on humanitarian grounds either . ORG considered that on essential points the applicant ’s account was vague and contradictory .
CARDINAL . Adopting the Advisory Board ’s proposal and reasoning , the Deputy Minister of ORG rejected the application for revision on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal against the Deputy Minister ’s decision with ORG ( Afdeling Rechtspraak ) of GPE , adding that the grounds for the appeal would be submitted as soon as possible . As this appeal was denied suspensive effect , the applicant instigated summary injunction proceedings before the President of ORG of The Hague sitting at GPE .
CARDINAL . Following a hearing on DATE the President of ORG , on DATE , granted the applicant an injunction against his expulsion pending the proceedings before ORG .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , the applicant ’s lawyer was informed by ORG on DATE that she had not so far submitted the grounds for the appeal with ORG and she was given the opportunity to comply with this requirement before DATE . The applicant ’s lawyer submitted grounds for the appeal on DATE , without providing an explanation for the delay .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG ( PERSON , the successor of ORG – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) in simplified proceedings ( vereenvoudigde procedure ) declared the applicant ’s appeal inadmissible for failure to comply with a formal requirement . The applicant lodged an objection ( verzet ) against this decision with ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of the applicant ’s objection , which took place on DATE , the applicant argued that it had not been possible to submit his grounds of appeal before DATE since it had been necessary , given that the Deputy Minister of ORG had disputed the authenticity of documents submitted by him , to try and obtain further proof of his allegations from GPE and that this had taken a long time .

CARDINAL . ORG rejected the applicant ’s objection on DATE , on the grounds that he had been given ample opportunity to submit his grounds of appeal , that he had been informed of the possible consequences of failure to do so and that , even if he considered it impossible to cure that failing in time , he ought to have submitted a request for an extension of the time - limit before it lapsed .
CARDINAL . Neither ORG nor its President in his decision of DATE examined the merits of the applicant ’s appeal .
CARDINAL . Mr ORG applied to the Commission on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , Mr ORG had lodged a second application for a residence permit , arguing that he had been legally resident in the GPE for DATE already . On being given notice that he would be expelled from the GPE on DATE , he brought summary injunction proceedings before the President of ORG for a suspension of the expulsion order . A hearing took place on DATE .

CARDINAL . At that hearing it transpired that Mr ORG had lodged new applications for refugee status or , in the alternative , a residence permit on humanitarian grounds on DATE , arguing that the second declaration issued by PERSON and the certified copy of the complaint filed against him , as well as information provided by his lawyer in GPE , constituted new facts which the Deputy Minister of ORG had not been able to take into account when deciding on the applicant ’s initial applications . In view of this information the representative of the Deputy Minister of ORG promised that the applications of DATE and CARDINAL DATE would be considered together and that the applicant would not be expelled in the meantime .
In a single decision of CARDINAL DATE , the Deputy Minister of ORG rejected both applications .

According to the Government , Mr ORG , through his lawyer , appealed against this decision to ORG , but failed to submit any grounds therefor within the time - limits set for that purpose . His appeal was declared inadmissible for that reason on DATE . The applicant did not lodge any objection against that decision .
CARDINAL . In so far as it is relevant to the present case , LAW relating to LAW DATE ( the DATE LAW ) , as amended by the LAW relating to LAW DATE , defines the term “ refugee ” as follows :

“ … any person who … owing to a well - founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion , is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or , owing to such fear , is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country ; or who , not having a nationality and being outside the country of his former habitual residence , is unable or , owing to such fear , is unwilling to return to it . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW prohibits the expulsion or return of a refugee to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion .
The GPE are party to both the convention and the protocol .

CARDINAL . Under LAW ) of LAW ( vreemdelingenwet ) , aliens coming from a country where they have a well - founded reason to fear persecution on account of their religious or political conviction , or of belonging to a particular race or a particular social group , may be admitted by the Minister of Justice as refugees .

The expression “ refugee ” in this provision is construed to have the same meaning as in the DATE LAW , as amended ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ; decision of ORG of the Raad van State of CARDINAL DATE , PERSON – Immigration Law Reports DATE , no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Aliens , other than refugees , wishing to reside in the GPE for any length of time have to hold a residence permit ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) . Such a permit is applied for to , and granted by , the Minister of Justice ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Given the situation obtaining in the GPE with regard to population size and employment , government policy is aimed at restricting the number of aliens admitted to the GPE . In general , aliens are only granted admission for residence purposes if :
( a ) the GPE are obliged under international law to do so , as in the case of citizens of ORG or GPE member GPE and refugees covered by the above - mentioned LAW ; or
( b ) this serves “ essential interests of the GPE ” , e.g. economic or cultural interests ; or
( c ) there are “ cogent reasons of a humanitarian nature ” ( klemmende PERSON aard ) .

CARDINAL . An alien who does not , or does no longer , qualify for admission to the GPE can be expelled ( section CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . However , aliens who claim that their removal from the GPE will compel them to travel to a country where they have reason to fear persecution on CARDINAL of the grounds set out in section CARDINAL ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) can not be expelled except by a specific order of the Minister of Justice ( section CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Prior to the entry into force of LAW on DATE , an alien could , in the event of a refusal to grant refugee status or a residence permit , apply in writing to the Minister of ORG for administrative revision of his decision ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . If such an application was not decided on DATE , it was deemed to have been refused ( section CARDINAL ) ) .

Such a request for revision did not suspend the alien ’s expulsion unless it was made DATE before the expiry of the period during which the alien was allowed to remain in the GPE ( section CARDINAL ) ) . It was , however , open to the Minister to decide that the request would have “ suspensive effect ” .

If suspensive effect was withheld , the alien could bring summary civil proceedings before the President of ORG for an injunction preventing his or her expulsion pending the Minister ’s decision . The latter decision , however , was not prejudged by such an injunction .

CARDINAL . The advice of ORG concerning Aliens had to be obtained if a request was made for revision of a decision to refuse refugee status to an alien who would be compelled as a result of such refusal to return to a country where he or she had reason to fear persecution ( section CARDINAL ) of LAW ) , or to expel an alien whose main place of residence for DATE or more had been in the GPE and who had complied with the formalities required by LAW ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(c ) taken together with section CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . In the event of a negative decision , or of failure to decide within due time , an appeal lay to ORG of the Raad van State ( section GPE ) of LAW ) .

However , such an appeal had no suspensive effect if the Minister ’s decision was in accordance with the advice of ORG concerning Aliens ( section CARDINAL ) ) ; in such a case , the alien could seek an injunction preventing his expulsion pending the decision of ORG in summary civil proceedings before the President of ORG . Like the Minister ’s decision ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the decision of ORG was not prejudged by such an injunction .

CARDINAL . An alien appealing to ORG of the Raad van State had to submit grounds of appeal and , if possible , all documents pertaining to the dispute ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of GPE ( PERSON ) . If this was not done at the time the appeal was lodged , the opportunity would be offered to do so at DATE , within a time - limit to be set by the President of ORG ; failure to comply with that time - limit could lead to a decision declaring the appeal inadmissible ( section CARDINAL ) . Such a decision could be given by the President of ORG in simplified proceedings ( section CARDINAL ) ) .
An objection lay , within DATE , to a Chamber of ORG ( section DATE ) ) .
CARDINAL . The entry into force of LAW on DATE brought extensive changes to the procedural provisions of LAW .
